To strengthen the interface effect of Pt with MnOx, manganese oxides with different defective concentration were obtained via removing oxygen under reduction treatment. The excellent performance on the Pt-based oxidation catalyst with optimum reduction temperature is 250 °C, and it's the light-off temperature of CO, C3H6 and NO are 170 °C, 180 °C and 185 °C, respectively, and the highest NO maximum conversion of 76%. The defect on MnOx could induce the adsorption of Pt2+ to produce the higher platinum dispersion and more active oxygen species. The abundant oxygen vacancies on manganese manganite would transfer to the subsurface, reducing the Mn valence and affecting the electronic effect of Pt with MnOx. Meanwhile, the existence of interfacial structure induces the shrinkage of platinum cell with the reduction of lattice parameter, because of the doping of Mn ion. The strong interaction of Pt with MnOx could promote the reduction of manganese oxides at the lower temperature. The interface of Pt-MnOx could accelerate the oxygen mobility and facilitate the formation of more bridged nitrates and chelating nitrates. Due to the interfacial structure of Pt with MnOx, the low temperature catalytic performance and high NO conversion of catalyst are remarkably improved. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Manganese oxide Defect Platinum-based oxidation catalyst Dispersion Active oxygen 1 Introduction Catalytic elimination in vehicle emission has attracted great attention for its high efficiency to meet strict emission limit [1–3]. In diesel after treatment system, there has integrated with diesel oxidation catalyst(DOC), diesel particle filter(DPF), selective catalytic reduced(SCR) and ammonic slip catalyst(ASC) [4–6]. For the front DOC, the basic role is to purify CO and hydrocarbon, and oxidize NO to NO2 [7,8]. The cold-start process of DOC restrict the low-temperature activity of SCR, and higher NO conversion could promote the soot oxidation in DPF and accelerate the de-NOx efficiency in SCR [9–12]. Both are pressing to decrease elimination at a lower temperature range to meet the present and prospective emission regulation in the engine exhaust during the initial cold-start period of engine operation. Universally, Pt-based DOC have been applied to efficiently oxidize the diesel emission [10,13-15]. In catalytic process, the exposed sites of platinum is crucial, while the aggregation of platinum could not be avoided at an accelerating temperature. Many researchers have found that the introduction of promoter is a convenient and efficient method to retard the migration of platinum atom [16,17]. Meanwhile, the optimization of promoter play a significant influence in tuning metal-support interaction. Jones et al [18]. found that the physically mixed polyhedral and nanorods ceria with Pt/La-Al2O3 have a higher reactivity than the ceria cubes, which contributes to the higher efficiency of polyhedral ceria and nanorods than ceria cubes at stabilizing platinum atoms. For the octahedral ceria that platinum cations prefer, there is six-fold coordination with surrounding oxygens, yet the eight-fold coordination on cube ceria. Further, Tao et al [19]. reported that rich oxygen vacancies on nanorod ceria could modify the dispersion of Pt. These works enlighten the fact that the surficial oxygen defect of metal oxides is the well sites to anchor Pt2+, affecting the electronic and structural interaction with platinum. To fabricate the oxygen vacancy on the surface of catalysts, there mainly involve doping, acid etching and surface deoxidation. Yang et al [20]. prepared the different Mn/Zr ratio solid solution to form oxygen defect by partially substituting Zr4+ with Mn2+. Yao et al [21]. reported that the CeO2 pretreated with H2SO4 could increase the amount of Ce3+ and the defect sites, contributing to the excellent catalytic performance. Besides, Zhu group [22] adopted the vacuum deoxidation method to enhance the ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ via tuning the temperature and time of vacuum deoxidation, and the optimum treatment temperature at 200 °C for 4 h. Similarly, the reduction atmosphere is introduced to construct the defective TiO2 for anchoring Au species [23]. While the correlated mechanism about modulating of surficial defect and anchoring of noble metal sites are the great challenge to synthesis catalysts. In CO/C3H6/NO oxidation reaction on DOC, active oxygen species are vital for accelerating the process. MnOx is universal in catalytic oxidation for the well reserve oxygen ability, which could conduce the catalytic performance when introducing Pt-based catalysts [24–26]. Recently, Umicore [27] and BASF corporation [28] pay attention to introduce manganese in carrier oxide on diesel oxidation catalysts to improve the NO oxidation ability(reaction window and maximum conversion). In this work, the prepared manganese oxides are pretreated in reduction gases at different temperature to tune the different surficial oxygen defective concentration. Then the modified promoter would control the anchoring effect for platinum species. Moreover, the influence of oxygen vacancy on platinum particle and the corresponding catalytic reaction process is elucidated by TEM and in situ DRIFTs. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The mixture of 7.9 g KMnO4 and 0.6 ml HCl (36–38%) were dissolved in 70 ml H2O, and then transferred to Teflon reactor placed in a sealed autoclave and were heated at 140 °C for 12 h. The precipitated MnOx samples were collected though centrifugation and repeatedly washing with deionized (DI) water prior to being dried at 100 °C for 6 h and calcinated at 500 °C for 3 h. Then the manganese oxide were reduced at different temperature (200 °C, 250 °C and 300 °C) for 2 h in 5 vol.% H2/N2 flow. The reduced manganese oxides (5 mass%) are physically mixed with (30 mass%) SiO2-Al2O3(150 m2/g, Solvay). The solution including 5 mass% PVA and 1 mass% Pt were introduced to adsorb on the mixed materials. After drying at 60 °C for 12 h, the samples were calcinated at 400 °C for 2 h in N2 flow and then at 550 °C for 3 h in air. The obtained powder is used to the prepare the monolithic catalyst with the calcination at 550 °C for 3 h in air. The total loading amount of 150 g/L. The final catalysts were labelled as R200, R250 and R300. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw in Via Reflex Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin Yvon, France) with 532 nm excitation wavelength, and the frequency collected is in the range of 200–800 cm−1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of catalysts were obtained by JEOL JES-FA200 spectrometer at 25 °C. XRD analyses were conducted using a Rigaku (Ultima IV) X-ray diffractometer, equipped with Cu Kα radiation, which is operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with a 0.02° step size scanning from 10° to 80°(2θ). High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images were performed by using Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN (FEI Company, USA) with an accelerating voltage of 200 KV. CO adsorbed DRIFT spectra was performed on a Niclolet 6700 spectrometer at atmospheric pressure. Before exposed to 1 vol.% CO/N2 at room temperature till saturation coverage, the sample was reduced at 450 °C for 30 min in 5 vol.% H2/N2. Then a flow of N2 was introduced to purge the gas CO. The spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction(H2-TPR) was conducted in a quartz micro-reactor and the front of detector (TCD) is equipped with a drying tube (CaCl2) to trap water. After pretreating at 450 °C for 30 min in N2 flow and cooling to room temperature, 0.1 g sample was exposed to a flow of 5 vol.% H2/N2 mixture and heated at a rate of 10 °C/min. Oxygen-temperature programmed desorption(O2-TPD) was performed on the same reactor and same pretreatment procedure. After adsorbing 5 vol.% O2/N2 for 30 min at room temperature and purging in N2, 0.1 g sample was heated at a rate of 10°C/min in N2 flow. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) data were performed with an electron spectrometer (Kratas AXIS SUPRA, Shimadzu Co.) equipped with an Al Kα radiation as a primary excitation. Binding energies were calculated on the basis of C 1s at 284.6 eV. In situ DRIFTs were obtained on Niclolet 6700 spectrometer equipped with mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen and the reaction cell with KBr windows. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst is pretreated at 450 °C for 30 min in He and cooling down. The mixed reaction gases include the flow of 5000 ppm CO, 1600 ppm C3H6, 1000 ppm NO, N2 balance with 300 ml/min. The spectra are recorded at different adsorption time from 1 min to 20 min and by accumulating 60 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Then 5 % O2/N2 are introduced to the system with the total flow rate of 300 ml/min. The spectra were collected at different reaction temperature from 50 °C to 350 °C. Then the background spectra were subtracted from the sample spectra in Kubelka−Munk (KM) units at the corresponding reaction temperature. 2.3 Catalytic measurements The catalytic activity of monolithic catalysts was evaluated by CO, C3H6 and NO oxidation using continuous-flow fix-bed reactor operated at atmospheric pressure. The feed gas was 200 ppm NO, 330 ppm C3H6, 1000 ppm CO, 10 vol.% O2, 7 vol.% H2O, and 8 vol.% CO2 and balanced by N2 with a 2500 ml/min flow rate and 60 kh−1 space velocity. A pretreatment under reaction mixture was applied at 550 °C for 1 h before the catalytic tests. The concentration of reaction mixture was online analyzed with FTIR analyzer(Thermo Fisher Scientific, Antaris IGS-6700) and the reactant conversion was defined by the following Eqs. (1), (2) and (3): (1) CO c o n v e r s i o n = ( [ CO ] i n l e t − [ CO ] o u t l e t ) / [ CO ] i n l e t * 100 % (2) HC c o n v e r s i o n = ( [ HC ] i n l e t − [ HC ] o u t l e t ) / [ HC ] i n l e t * 100 % (3) NO c o n v e r s i o n = [ N O 2 ] o u t l e t / [ N O x ] o u t l e t * 100 % Where the subscript as inlet and outlet, which stands for the inlet concentration and the outlet concentration, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of all catalysts is evaluated in the flow of simulated diesel emission, the oxidation sequences is as follows: CO, C3H6 and NO. It is consistent with the report [29], the strong adsorption of CO inhibit the C3H6 and NO oxidation. Meanwhile, CO and C3H6 could reduce NO2 at low temperature, the production of NO oxidation, resulting in the NO oxidation after CO and C3H6 Fig. 1 . displays the distinct difference in CO, C3H6 and NO conversion temperature, and NO maximum conversion on all tested catalysts. It could be found that R250 exhibits the superior catalytic performance than R200, as well as R300. As listed in Table 1 , the light-off temperature of CO(T50, the temperature at 50% conversion), C3H6(T50) and NO(T30, the temperature at 30% conversion) on R250 are 170 °C, 180 °C and 185 °C, respectively. In comparison, R200 and R300 exhibit CO(T50)/C3H6(T50)/NO(T30) value of 205 °C/215°C/229°C, 213°C/221°C/232°C, respectively. And the full conversion temperature (T90, the temperature at 90% conversion) also shows the similar tendency as the sequence of R250<R200<R300. Additionally, R250 has the highest NO maximum conversion (76%), which is around 63% on R200 and 53% on R300. Meanwhile, the temperature at NO maximum conversion on R200 and R300 increases by around 50 °C than on R250 at 240 °C. The difference in the light-off temperature, full-conversion temperature and NO maximum conversion between R200, R250 and R300 could be attributed to the different interaction of Pt with MnOx from different reduction degree of MnOx. A possible explanation for the difference is that R250 increases the number of sites that form Pt-MnOx interfaces. More interfacial sites could promote the formation of active oxygen species.[30] With an increased reduction temperature of MnOx, the surficial oxygen atoms could be gradually removed till to the transformation of phase. According to the reference [22], extent of oxygen vacancy could be adjusted by tuning the temperature, which could change the charge distribution. As it is, the variation in reduction temperature could affect the extent of losing oxygen. Moderately oxygen losing could form the oxygen vancies, and once exceeding the point the phase could be broken to form a new phase. From the results of conversion curves, the reduction temperature at 250 °C might be the key point, whose concentration of oxygen vancies is highest, resulting in an excellent catalytic performance on R250. 3.2 Structural properties The difference of all catalysts lies in the difference of MnOx with different reduction treatment. To further investigate the inner reason, it could trace to the properties of initial MnOx. The phase structure of initial MnOx and reduced MnOx via Raman spectra are compared Fig. 2 . presents the main peaks at 572 cm−1 and 619 cm−1 on the initial MnOx and low-temperature reduced MnOx, indicating the well-developed tetragonal structure with the stretching vibration of Mn–O and symmetric stretching vibration of MnO6 group.[22] With the reduced temperature from 200 °C to 250 °C, the vibration band at 619 cm−1 are gradually disappeared, verifying the gradual removal of surficial oxygen on MnOx. And excess surficial oxygen removal would result in the phase transformation. According to the spectra of MnOx after reduced treatment at 300 °C, there appears the strong band centered at about 652 cm−1. It belongs to the stretching of Mn2O3, [31] which is consistent with the obvious Mn2O3 phase from following XRD results. Thus, it could be speculated that the reduction temperature at 250°C is the key point to create the threshold value owning most oxygen vacancies. As it is, the lower reduction temperature on MnOx could not own the higher oxygen vancies. To verify this thought, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) profiles of the final catalysts (R200 and R250) are presented in Fig. 2(b). Both has a symmetrical EPR signal peak at g=2.000, which could be assigned to unpaired electrons that was created from of atmospheric oxygen onto surficial oxygen vacancies of catalysts, as the reference[22] reminded it. In contrast to the signal intensity, R250 exhibit a stronger signal than R200, manifesting that the surficial oxygen vacancy of R250 is higher than R200. The difference of surficial defect on MnOx could directly affect the adsorbed state of Pt species on the surface of support, which has an important influence in the structural property and chemical state of platinum. To confirm structural difference of MnOx and Pt, X-Ray diffraction peaks are intuitively to reflect the variation in phase as the function of reduced temperature Fig. 3.(a) displays the standard cards of MnO2 and Mn2O3, as well as the diffraction patterns of catalysts with the reduced temperature of 200 °C, 250 °C and 300 °C. There is weak characteristic Mn2O3(222) peak at 32.9 ° detected on R200 and R250, yet it gets stronger on R300. The results indicate that the reduction pretreatment of MnOx (below 250 °C) could not obviously affect the transformation in phase and the phase transformation from MnO2 to Mn2O3 appear at the reduction temperature of 300 °C. Additionally, MnO2(310) phase at 28.8 ° also could not appear on R200 and R250, indicating the existence of well-dispersed MnOx. It could speculate that the variation in MnOx phase has a great influence on the catalytic performance. To reveal the inner mechanism of R250, the following analysis would be centered on the comparison of R200, R250 and R300 in structural and surficial properties. The amplified diffraction peak of Pt(111) is displayed in Fig. 3(b), and it could be observed the decreased trend of diffraction intensity as the sequence of R300>R200>R250, indicating the larger particle size on R300. In comparison to R300 and R200, Pt(111) on R250 shows a higher 2θ value, then the lattice distance gets smaller according to the Bragg equation, along with the smaller lattice parameter in Table 2 . It speculates the inner reason that the relatively smaller ion radius of Mn4+ partially access to the unit cell of platinum, illustrating the strong interaction of Pt with manganese oxides. TEM characterization is performed to investigate the change of crystallite size of the catalysts in Fig. 4(a-c), alongside the corresponding particle size distributions. As seen in Fig. 4(a-c), the black particles are the platinum particles dispersing on support due to the highest relative atom mass of platinum comparing to other elements in the catalytic system. Intuitively, it could be observed that the counts of platinum particles on R250 is relatively much more and its mostly platinum particles are relatively smaller than R200 and R300 at the same scale, indicating that platinum particles on R250 disperse more uniformly. Especially on R300, only several platinum particles are detected in Fig. 5(c). After statistical calculation about 100 platinum particles, Pt particle size of the catalysts are between 2 nm and 15 nm. In the case of R200 and R300, the mainly particle sizes are 5–11 nm, with the average platinum particle size of 6.5 nm and 7.9 nm as listed in Table 2, respectively. And the mainly particle size of 3–10 nm existing on R250, presenting the smaller platinum particles existing on support with the average platinum particle size of 6.0 nm. Based on the previous results about more surficial oxygen vacancy existing on R250, it could be assumed that the stronger interaction of Pt with MnOx on R250 induces the formation of surficial oxygen vacancies. Further, HRTEM image in Fig. 4(d) is presented to verify the assumption. The obvious round particle is the platinum particle, and the adjacent area appear the lattice fringe of 0.31 nm assigning to MnO2(310). The yellow line is labeled to show clearly the overlapped region, and the fringe is relatively vague where could be the interfacial district of Pt with MnO2. As it is, the surficial active oxygen species would be formed at this interface,[32] and the chemical state of the adjacent platinum could be affected. For investigating the exposed sites and chemical state of platinum, there displays the DRIFTs spectra of CO linear adsorbed at room temperature in Fig. 5 after the reduction pretreatment. The main adsorbed peak on R200 and R250 locate at 2092 cm−1 assigning to the linearly adsorbed CO on Pt0, which is at a higher wavenumber than on R300 (2073 cm−1). The obvious wavenumber shift suggests that the lower electron intensity of platinum on R200 and R250 due to the electronic interaction with manganese. Similar results have been reported by Song[16], the blue shift is due to the electron transfer from Pt to transition metal oxides. Besides, the adsorption area on catalysts follows the trend of R250>R200>R300 in the inset of Fig. 5, and R250 is 1.6-1.8 times than other two. It indicates the most exposed platinum sites existing on R250, which is in line with the results of XRD in Fig. 3(b). 3.3 Surficial properties The difference in structural properties about MnOx and Pt is related to the formation of Pt-MnOx interface. According to the report from Nakano[26], no Pt-Mn or Pt-O-Mn bond was observed by EXAFS, yet the higher coordination number of Pt-O bond on Mn-addition catalyst, indicating that no alloy or composite of Pt and Mn oxide formed, instead by the formation of unsaturated coordination of Pt. The kind of interaction could affect the redox properties of catalysts. All catalysts display the reduction of surficial oxides with the temperature below 400 °C in Fig. 6(a). The main reduction peak temperature on R200, R250 and R300 located at187 °C, 171 °C and 219 °C, respectively, which is assigned to the reduction of platinum oxides interacting with MnOx and surficial manganese oxides. Especially for R250, there has a weak reduction peak at 93 °C, belonging to the reduction of platinum oxides and MnOx clusters in vicinity of Pt. It would be guessed that the smaller platinum particles are formed and disperse on the surface of R250, where are easier oxidized in calcinate process. Notably, the reduction peak temperature lower by around 50 °C suggest that the strongest interaction of Pt with manganese on R250, resulting in the appearance of excellent redox properties. It is most likely that the interface between Pt/MnOx on R250 promoting the H2 spillover on MnOx contribute to the easier reduction of PtOx and MnOx than other. According to the report[32], the oxygen atoms at the boundary region between metal and oxide has a high reactivity, thus greatly modifying the reducibility. Meanwhile, the interfacial sites could promote the formation of active oxygen species. Oxygen desorption behaviors (below 300 °C) of catalysts are presented in Fig. 6(b), where the increased desorption peak temperature and decreased desorption amount of oxygen are reflected as the sequence of R250, R200 and R300. The higher active oxygen species and easier oxygen desorption on R250 would be crucial in oxidation performance. The surficial elements (Mn, Pt, O) are further detected though XPS to investigate the variation of chemical state. In Fig. 7(a), Mn 2p3/2 curve is divided into three peaks, Mn4+(640.8 eV), Mn3+(642.4 eV) and Mn2+ (644.8 eV). According to the reference [33], the variation in the chemical state of Mn is important characteristic to verify the strong interaction of oxides. After calculating, the percent of Mn4+/Mn gradually decrease from R200, R250 to R300, and the main phase of R300 is Mn2O3, which is line with the results of XRD. Due to the overlapped binding energy of Pt 4f and Al 2p, it is difficult to analyze the variation of platinum state. In Fig. 7(b), the Pt 4d3/2 peak of R300 and R200 locate at 331.3 eV, while R250 shows a 0.5 eV-shift to a higher binding energy. The obvious shift verifies the lesser electronic density of platinum due to the strong electronic interaction of Pt with MnOx. O 1s spectra in Fig. 7(c) includes two peaks, the lower binding energy peak assigning to latter oxygen (Oβ) and higher binding energy belonging to chemisorbed oxygen and oxygen vacancies(Oα) [34]. The data listed in Table 3 present that the percent of Oα on R250 is relatively high (43.1%), improved by around 12% than R300, in line with the higher oxygen desorption intensity deriving from O2-TPD. The mechanism of the DOC reaction for all catalysts are studied using in situ CO+C3H6+NO diffuse reflectance Fourier transform (DRIFT) technologies. To investigate the variation of adsorbed species at low reaction temperature, the varied process on R200 with an adsorption time at without and with oxygen condition at 50°C are presented in Fig. 8(a). With the introduction of only CO, C3H6 and NO at 1 min, there appears the vibration of hydrocarbon species (2943 cm−1, 3092 cm−1) might assigning to the formate intermediates [35], gas CO (2173 cm−1, 2121 cm−1), linear CO adsorption on Ptn+ (2088 cm−1), carboxylate species (1661 cm−1, 1637 cm−1) and acetate species (1445 cm−1) on R200. With an increased time to 20 min, all detected species present an increasing trend. After the introduction of oxygen, there sharply decreased for gas CO, formate and acetate species, while the carboxylate species (1637 cm−1) and hydroxyl species (3431 cm−1) gradually get stronger. Up to 5 min, there mainly exists the variation band at 3431 cm−1, 2000–2200 cm−1 and 1637 cm−1, indicating that the intermediate species of CO and C3H6 quickly react with oxygen and disappear, then left the slight gas CO, absorbed CO on Ptn+, hydroxy group and acetate species at 50 °C in the continuous mixture gases of CO+C3H6+NO+O2. The evolution of spectra with an increased temperature from 100°C to 350°C are recorded as seen in Fig. 8(b-d) in the flow of CO+C3H6+NO+O2 on all catalysts. At 100 °C, there has strong -OH species during the range from 3000–3500 cm−1, gas CO, linear CO-Pt and carboxylate species on R200. At 125 °C, the intensity of those species gradually decreased, indicating the occurrence of CO and HC oxidation. At 150 °C, the new band at 1618 cm−1 and 1585 cm−1 appear firstly, which are assigned to bridged and chelating nitrates, respectively,[36] and which are presented as an increased trend up to 300 °C. Then the ionic nitrates (1391 cm−1) begin to form at 190 °C and gradually accumulate up to 300°C. Meanwhile, platinum species are oxidized at above 250 °C, resulting in that the band of linear Pt-CO peak at 2080 cm−1 transforms to 2120 cm−1 and the intensity decrease. With higher platinum oxides forming, the linear Pt-CO peak At 350°C, bridged and chelating nitrates and ionic nitrates decrease, while convert to the linear nitrite nitrites (1453 cm−1) [37]. In comparison, the intensity of -OH, carboxylate and nitrates follow the trends of R250>R200>R300. The phenomenon indicates that CO and C3H6 oxidation could react more efficient on R250 at 100 °C and contribute to the stronger band of -OH and carboxylate, presenting an excellent low-temperature activity. Meanwhile, the higher intensity of NO oxidation reaction intermediates (bridged nitrates, chelating nitrates and ionic nitrates) on R250 is beneficial for NO conversion. For the detected intermediate species about NO oxidation, bridged and chelating nitrates are relatively obvious band. The formation and decomposition ability of nitrates are the vital intermediate species in NO oxidation pathway [38]. It would strengthen the learning to analysis the variation trend of bridged nitrates (1618 cm−1) and chelating nitrates (1585 cm−1), as presented in Fig. 9 . The intensity of bridged nitrates and chelating nitrates are gradually increased with an accelerated temperature. From the evolution process of bridged nitrates and chelating nitrates in Fig. 8, two peak could be transformed to one with the reaction temperature at above 230 °C, which is difficult to directly distinct the peak intensity. The peak intensity of bridged nitrates (1618 cm−1) and chelating nitrates (1585 cm−1) are basically consistent in varied trend during the temperature range from 150 to 230 °C. Intuitively, R250 has the more bridged nitrates and chelating nitrates, which is around twice and four-times than on R200 and R300, respectively. It indicates that the more active intermediate species formed on the surface of R250 when oxidizing NO, in line with the variation tend in NO oxidation curves. 3.4 Interactions of Pt with MnOx As described as Scheme 1 , the prepared MnOx are pretreated at different temperature in the reduction atmosphere to construct the surficial defect sites. With the reduction temperature exceeding the 250 °C, MnOx would be transformed to Mn2O3 which has less oxygen species compared to high valence state of Mn4+ [39]. To ensure the high surface area, moderately reduced MnOx is regarded as the promoter to modify the support (SiO2–Al2O3). Then the introduction of Pt2+ could be inclined to adsorb at the vicinity of defect sites to form the Pt/MnOx interface, which is likely to affect the formation of oxidized platinum and improve the dispersion of nano platinum. The CO oxidation mechanism at the Pt/MnOx interface have been investigated by Gao et al [40]., their DFT results show that surface lattice oxygen firstly to participate the oxidation behavior, along with the formation of oxygen vacancy which then could be complemented by dissociated oxygen, further to participate the second oxidation process. Such oxidation process on the interface sites lead to the lower energy barriers on interface (3.45 Kcal/mol) than on only Pt sites (8.76 Kcal/mol) [40]. Meanwhile, Pt on vacancies sites of MnOx could form the dynamic equilibrium of charge state, resulting in the formation of metallic Pt and active oxygen species. The oxidation of CO/C3H6/NO obeys the Mars and van Krevelen mechanism and active oxygen species are crucial in facilitating oxidation process. The higher active oxygen species on R250 facilitate the formation of carboxylate species, formate species and bridged/chelating nitrates species, greatly improving the oxidation ability. 4 Conclusions The interaction between Pt with MnOx is tuned by pretreating at different temperature in reduced atmosphere before loading platinum. The optimum temperature is at 250 °C to establish the high oxygen defect concentration and the phase transformation at a higher temperature. More surficial oxygen defect concentration is favorable to strengthen the interaction of Pt with MnOx, resulting in the smaller platinum particles and electron deficiency of platinum. When Pt locating on the surficial defect of MnOx, the dynamic equilibrium of charge state promotes the formation of metallic Pt and active oxygen species. Both are favorable of the activation of reaction gases, facilitating the intermediate production of carboxylate, formate and bridged/chelating nitrates. This work provides an efficient way to strengthen the interaction of Pt with MnOx, which is also be appropriate for other supported catalysts to change the support properties and provide the more active oxygen species. coredata.dc:description: To strengthen the interface effect of Pt with MnOx, manganese oxides with different defective concentration were obtained via removing oxygen under reduction treatment. The excellent performance on the Pt-based oxidation catalyst with optimum reduction temperature is 250 °C, and it's the light-off temperature of CO, C3H6 and NO are 170 °C, 180 °C and 185 °C, respectively, and the highest NO maximum conversion of 76%. The defect on MnOx could induce the adsorption of Pt2+ to produce the higher platinum dispersion and more active oxygen species. The abundant oxygen vacancies on manganese manganite would transfer to the subsurface, reducing the Mn valence and affecting the electronic effect of Pt with MnOx. Meanwhile, the existence of interfacial structure induces the shrinkage of platinum cell with the reduction of lattice parameter, because of the doping of Mn ion. The strong interaction of Pt with MnOx could promote the reduction of manganese oxides at the lower temperature. The interface of Pt-MnOx could accelerate the oxygen mobility and facilitate the formation of more bridged nitrates and chelating nitrates. Due to the interfacial structure of Pt with MnOx, the low temperature catalytic performance and high NO conversion of catalyst are remarkably improved.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced performance of Pt-based diesel oxidation catalyst via defective MnOx: The role of Pt/MnOx interface
